title: Free Alternatives to Arial?
content:
I am to be doing my first real (like, paid even) design job. My client is wanting business cards, a letterhead and some other pre-press work done. I believe the business is multimedia.   
   
For his business card, he is wanting me to use Arial, because it is clean and simple etc. I think the reason for this is he either doesn't realise there are other typefaces available to purchase, (which could lend the design a distinctive quality and hint of character) or does not want to invest.   
   
I am scheduled to work initially for 4 hours, by the way. (this could be a squeeze \>\_\< )   
   
So, I am looking to some free alternatives to Arial in the mean-time. I would even rather use Helvetica. (it's just more well crafted). I also don't think he would want to go to the extra trouble of purchasing a font considering the duration of my employment.   
   
Alternatives anyone? Thanks   
   
- Chris
author: Chris Washer

comments.content: Chris, did you do a Google Search? Also take a trip to DaFont and hunt through their Sans list.

_A free alternate to 'Arial'.?_ I always thought 'Arial' was the free 'alternate' to 'Helvetica'.? ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150424013035im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/bigsmile.gif)

Hah, I actually have a little trouble discerning free from comes-with-the-computer sometimes. I thought Gill Sans was a font you had to buy, but I have it somehow. Who knows? Probably part of a freeware office-type program. hmm.   
   
You're right Daniel. I did do a google search, but I got discouraged by the number of results. Perhaps I should have just asked for a few comprehensive free font sites. I am quite weary of wading through million hit searches for pages with thousands of possible searchs designed to just get a hit.   
   
Sorry, I ramble.   
   
Many thanks Daniel. I lost the bit of paper my typography tutor gave me with all the free type sites.   
   
- Chris

_Noo, Sorry.._ Seriously, What about ' [Mank Sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20150424013035/http:/moorstation.org/typoasis/designers/klein04/text/manksans.htm)', or ' [Sansumi](http://web.archive.org/web/20150424013035/http:/moorstation.org/typoasis/designers/klein04/text/sansumi.htm)', by Manfred Klein.?

Ohh, Mank Sans is quite good. I like Communist from Dafont, looks quite... like a bought one. They have a few bitstream fonts floating around there. I also found bitsream Vera lying around the net... has this been surrendered to the masses? I suppose some foundries do free fonts.   
   
- Chris
